sen.j: 長岡天満宮（ながおかてんまんぐう）は、京都府長岡京市に鎮座する神社（天満宮）。
sen.e: Nagaoka Tenmangu is a shrine(tenmangu) located in Nagaokakyo City, Kyoto Prefecture
Nagaoka Tenmangu is a shrine (tenmangu) located in Nagaokakyo City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Nagaoka Tenmangu is a shrine (tenmangu) located in Nagaokakyo City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Origin
Origin
Origin

sen.j: 菅原道真が太宰府に左遷となった際、この地に立ち寄った縁故により創立されたという。
sen.e: It is said that the shrine was founded because SUGAWARA no Michizane stopped here on his way to Dazai-fu(local government office in Kyushu region) where he was banished.
It is said that the shrine was founded because SUGAWARA no Michizane stopped here on his way to Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region) where he was banished.
It is said that the shrine was founded because SUGAWARA no Michizane stopped here on his way to Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region) where he was banished.
Reisai (an annual festival) is held on October 10th.
Reisai (an annual festival) is held on October 10.
Reisai (an annual festival) is held on October 9.

sen.j: 1638年（寛永15年）に八条宮智仁親王によって「八条ヶ池」が築造された。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Hachijonomiya Toshihito Hachijogaike Pond was made in 1638 by the command of Imperial Prince Hachijonomiya Toshihito.
Imperial Prince Hachijonomiya Toshihito Hachijogaike Pond was made in 1638 by the command of Imperial Prince Hachijonomiya Toshihito.
Hachijogaike Pond was made in 1638 by the command of Imperial Prince Hachijonomiya Toshihito.

sen.j: 八条ヶ池のキリシマツツジは有名で、隣接する長岡公園の梅園も広く知られている。
sen.e: Kirishima azalea at Hachijogaike Pond is famous, and so is the Japanese-apricot orchard in Nagaoka Park next to the pond.
Kirishima azalea at Hachijogaike Pond is famous, and so is the Japanese-apricot orchard in Nagaoka Park next to the pond.
Kirishima azalea at Hachijogaike Pond is famous, and so is the Japanese-apricot orchard in Nagaoka Park next to the pond.

sen.j: 算額 寛政2年(1790) 中嶌敬軸門人今堀彌吉奉納（収蔵）
sen.e: Sangaku (Japanese votive tablets featuring mathematical puzzles) dedicated by Yakichi IMAHORI, a desciple of Keijiku NAKAJIMA, in 1790(stored item)
Sangaku (Japanese votive tablets featuring mathematical puzzles) dedicated by Yakichi IMAHORI, a disciple of Keijiku NAKAJIMA, in 1790 (stored item)

sen.j: 阪急京都本線長岡天神駅より西へ徒歩 10分
sen.e: A ten-minute walk westward from Nagaokatenjin Station on Hankyu Kyoto Line.
